title: Speedometer on a Bike Wheel

children.value:
The reading of a speedometer fitted to the front wheel of a bicycle is directly proportional to the angular speed of the wheel. A certain speedometer is correctly calibrated for use with a wheel of diameter 
$\quantity{66}{cm}$
 but, by mistake, is fitted to a 
$\quantity{60}{cm}$
 wheel.

answer.value:
Attaching the speedometer to a bike that has a smaller wheel radiuswill give a calculated linear speed that is too great, since the angular speed will be multiplied by $\quantity{0.66}{m}$ instead of the actual $\quantity{0.60}{m}$ . The percentage error is simply given by

$\displaystyle \frac{66-60}{60}\cdot 100=10#37; $

children.value: Explain whether the indicated linear speed would be greater or less than the actual linear speed and find the percentage error in the readings.
